STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 29, 2020
Jennifer Schmidt
Mecosta/Osceola DHHS
800 Water Tower Road
Big Rapids, MI 49307
RE: License #: CP540201288
Mecosta/Osceola DHHS
800 Water Tower Road
Big Rapids, MI 49307
Dear Ms. Schmidt:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
10/22/20. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be
noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the ISEP
and policy. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 For any repeat violations, include an assessment of why the previous
corrective action plan was ineffective.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 552-3662.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Rorie Dodge-Garnaat, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
235 Grand, Ste 1305
P.O. Box 30650
Lansing, MI 48909
(517) 899-6024
enclosure
2

DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12323 Emergency policy.
(1) An agency's emergency policy shall, at a minimum, contain
provisions for ensuring that a foster parent has agency-
approved written procedures for each of the following
emergencies:
(a) Fire.
1 of 6 foster home files reviewed did not have an indication that the foster home was
practicing the emergency procedures.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(2) The annual reevaluation shall include a determination and
assessment of all of the following:
(b) Family functioning and interrelationships as determined
by observation of, and interviews with, each member of the
household and each social service worker who has had children
placed in the home during the last licensing period.
1 of 6 foster home reevaluations reviewed did not include input from the Foster Care
worker.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(c) Conduct a thorough investigation including all necessary
collateral contacts.
3 of 5 Special Evaluation reports reviewed did not indicate in the report that a
thorough investigation was completed.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any treatment
required for each child who is 4 years of age and older,
including both of the following:
4

(i) A dental examination within 12 months before
placement or a new dental examination shall be completed not
more than 90 calendar days after placement.
(ii) A dental reexamination shall be obtained at least every
18 months, unless a greater frequency is indicated.
1 of 3 foster care files reviewed did not have documentation that a dental exam was
completed.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
agency is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Policy violation. Please note that
there are additional DHS Policy requirements that may not be included in section
1. The agency is in compliance will all additional DHS Policy requirements except
for the following:
FOM 801 Medical Passports
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• The child’s foster care provider:
At or prior to each placement.
Quarterly.
Medical Passport Receipt Documentation
Receipt of the medical passport by the required parties is
documented in MiSACWIS by uploading the signed and dated
signature page into the Health Profile section.
2 of 3 foster care files reviewed were missing quarterly medical passports signed by
the caregiver.
FOM 722-06H CASEWORKER CONTACT CHILD IN OUT-OF-HOME
PLACEMENT
The caseworker must have at least two face-to-face contacts
per month with the child for the first two months following an
initial placement or a placement move.
5

1 of 3 foster care files reviewed did not have a second face to face visit between the
youth and the caseworker in the first month after a placement.
FOM 722-06H TIMELY ENTRY OF CASEWORKER CONTACTS
All face-to-face contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS, within
five business days of the contact.
2 of 3 Foster care files reviewed did not have timely entry of face to face contacts.
722-06B Family Team Meetings
The following events shall trigger FTM for out of home cases:
• Case service plan development,
• permanency goal changes,
• placement preservation/disruption
• permanency planning at six months in care annual transition
planning for youth every six months from age 16 until case
closure
• 90 day discharge planning for youth
• Case closure
1 of 1 Independent living file reviewed did not have an FTM prior to being placed in
Independent Living
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Document in the social work contacts any attempts that were made to go over
PATP with birth parents as well as attempts made to get signatures.
 Documents explaining the Independent living program should be given to
youth in Independent living. A form for them to sign can be proof that the
documents were given.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request consultation at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The agency has not been required to submit any corrective action plans during this
licensing period.
6

The agency does not have any repeat violations as they were not found in violation
of any rules or policy requirements during their 2019 Interim inspection.
VII. ANALYST FINDINGS
The field analyst visited 3 foster homes and 3 relative homes. There were not any
safety concerns noted in any of the homes. Any service concerns were addressed
with agency management during the entrance conference.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules, ISEP, and/or policy requirements. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
10/28/20
________________________________________
Rorie Dodge-Garnaat Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
October 29, 2020
________________________________________
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
